item.title: $\subset$ and $\in$
item.description: $\subset$ and $\in$ The [[notes/subsets|subset]] symbol $\subset$ is only used when referring to sets and not individual elements inside the sets.

item.title: Asymmetric Relations
item.description: Asymmetric Relations A [[notes/relations|relation]] $R$ is asymmetric if each pair of different elements does not have its inverse in the relation.

item.title: Basic Data Analysis in Python
item.description: Basic Data Analysis in Python 1 2 import pandas as pd import numpy as np The two most important libraries in data analysis are Pandas and NumPy.

item.title: Bernoulli's Equation
item.description: Bernoulli’s Equation Bernoulli’s equation states that the properties of a fluid in one part of a system should be constant.

item.title: Bisection Method
item.description: Bisection Method This method looks to find the roots of a nonlinear equation. First we find the range $[a,b]$ over which we want to check for roots.

item.title: Canonical Base
item.description: Canonical Base Canonical base in $\mathbb{R}^2$: $$ \begin{align} e_i= \begin{bmatrix} 1 \ 0 \end{bmatrix} && e_2= \begin{bmatrix} 0 \ 1 \end{bmatrix} && \longrightarrow && \begin{bmatrix} e_1 & e_2 \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \end{align} $$

item.title: Cardinality
item.description: Cardinality In [[notes/set-theory|set theory]], the cardinality of set $A$ is the size of set $A$, $|A|$. #logic #setTheory

item.title: Cartesian Product
item.description: Cartesian Product Let $A$ and $B$ be two non empty [[notes/set-union|sets]]. The Cartesian Product of these sets is the set of ordered pairs, which in turn, becomes a [[notes/relations|relation]].

item.title: Chain Rule
item.description: Chain Rule $$ \frac{dy}{dx}=\frac{dy}{du}\cdot \frac{du}{dx} $$ #math #calculus

item.title: Chain rule with multiple variables
item.description: Chain rule with multiple variables When applying the [[chain rule]] to [[notes/multivariable-functions|functions with multiple]] variables, we must keep in mind that each of our internal functions can have several variables as well.

item.title: Compound Propositions
item.description: Compound Propositions [[notes/propositions|Propositions]] formed by 2 or more simple propositions, connected with [[notes/logical-connectors|logical connectors]], e.g, and, or, if. #logic

item.title: Consistency of a SLE
item.description: Consistency of a SLE A [[notes/linear-equation-systems|system]] is consider consistent if it has a [[notes/sle-solution|solution]], if not, it’s considered inconsistent. #logic #linearAlgebra

item.title: Coordinate Systems in 3 Dimensions
item.description: Coordinate Systems in 3 Dimensions Our 3 coordinates form 3 planes, $x, y, z$, which forms 8 quadrants. Points in this coordinate system have the form $P(x, y, z)$.

item.title: Correlation Coefficient
item.description: Correlation Coefficient Correlation is a measurement that determines if a variable can be a function of another. This is useful in determining whether or not a given variable actually effects the end result.

item.title: Coulomb's Law
item.description: Coulomb’s Law $$ F=\frac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_0}\frac{|q_1q_2|}{r^2} $$ The force of attraction between two electrically charged particles is inversely proportional to the distance between them.

item.title: cross-product
item.description: Cross Product Definition: If $a = \langle a_1,a_2,a_3\rangle$ and $b = \langle b_1,b_2,b_3\rangle$, then the cross product between $a$ and $b$ is defined as: $$ a\times b = \langle a_2b_3-a_3b_2, a_3b_1 - a_1b_3, a_1b_2-a_2-b_1\rangle $$

item.title: De Morgan's Law
item.description: De Morgan’s Law $$ \begin{rcases} (P \cup Q)^c = P^c \cap Q^c \ (P \cap Q)^c = P^c \cup Q^c \end{rcases} = \text{DeMorgan’s Law} $$ [[notes/set-union|Union]] $\cup$ is can be considered as addition $+$, and [[notes/set-intersection|intersection]] $\cap$ is multiplication $\times$.

item.title: derivation
item.description: Derivation Derivation is the act of finding the rate of change of some function. This can be interpreted physically as the slope on a given point of a curve.

item.title: Differential Equations
item.description: Differential Equations A differential equation is any equations that contains the derivative of one or more unknown functions. $$ a_n(x)\frac{\mathrm{d}^ny}{\mathrm{d}x^{n}}+a_{n-1}(x)\frac{\mathrm{d}^{n-1}y}{\mathrm{d}x^{n-1}}+\dots=y=g(x) $$

item.title: Directional Derivative
item.description: Directional Derivative [[notes/partial-derivatives|Partial derivatives]] show us rates of change in $x$ and $y$ for a given function $f(x, y)$. Now we’ll see rates of change on $f(x, y)$ in other directions, given by a vector $\vec{u}$.

item.title: Directional Derivatives in $\mathbb{R}^3$
item.description: Directional Derivatives in $\mathbb{R}^3$ The [[notes/directional-derivative|directional derivative]] in $f$ in the direction of $u$ is defined as: $$ D_uf(x_0,y_0,z_0)=f_x(x_0,y_0,z_0)u_1+f_y(x_0,y_0,z_0)u_2+f_z(x_0,y_0,z_0)u_3 $$ Let $f$ be a function of $3$ variables that is differentiable in $(x_0,y_0,z_0)$

item.title: Disjoint Sets
item.description: Disjoint Sets Sets $A$ and $B$ are disjoint sets if they have no elements in common, save for the [[notes/null-set|empty set]].

item.title: Divergence
item.description: Divergence The divergence of a vector field gives us information about the [[notes/flux]], and is calculated with: $$ divF=\nabla\cdot F=\frac{\partial F_{x}}{\partial x}\frac{\partial F_{y}}{\partial y}\frac{\partial F_{z}}{\partial z} $$

item.title: dot-product
item.description: Dot Product Definition: If $a = \langle a_1,a_2,a_3\rangle$ and $b\langle b_1,b_2,b_3\rangle$, then the dot product of $a$ and $b$ is given by: $$ a\cdot b = a_1b_1+a_2b_2+a_3b_3 $$

item.title: Double Integration
item.description: Double Integration Double integration is the act of [[notes/integration|integrating]] some function several times. This can be done on a second [[notes/derivation|derivative]] of a single function, or the first [[notes/derivation|derivative]] of a [[notes/multivariable-functions|multivariable function]].

item.title: Electric Field
item.description: Electric Field Two particles $A$ and $B$ exercise forces against each other. We remove the smaller of the particles and replace it with a point $P$.

item.title: Equation of Continuity
item.description: Equation of Continuity When dealing with fluids, the equation of continuity states that the [[notes/volume-flow-rate|flow rate]] between one area of a system is the same as the flow rate at another part of the system.

item.title: Equivalence Relation
item.description: Equivalence Relation An equivalence relation is a [[notes/relations|relation]] that is [[notes/reflexive-relations|reflexive]], [[notes/symmetric-relations|symmetric]], and [[notes/transitive-relations|transitive]]. It is the opposite of a [[notes/partial-order-relation|partially ordered relation]].

item.title: Evaluating Arguments
item.description: Evaluating Arguments Find the value of the following logical implication: $q, p\to q \models q$ Find the truth of each statement individually.

item.title: Expected Value
item.description: Expected Value Expected value can be considered as the average of the outcomes of a [[notes/random-variable|random variable]].

item.title: Experimental Uncertainty
item.description: Experimental Uncertainty Errors can appear from many different sources: Uncalibrated equipment Random errors Systematic errores Types of Uncertainty A: One must use a statistical procedure in order to find their numerical value.

item.title: Flux
item.description: Flux Flux is the measurement of flow, and is calculated using the [[notes/surface-integrals|integral]]: $$ \iint F\cdot \mathrm{d}S $$ When dealing with a flow field of the form $F(x,y,z)=Pi+Qj+Rk$, in some region $z=g(x,y)$, this integral can be rewritten as: $$ \iint\left( -P\frac{\partial g}{\partial x} - Q\frac{\partial g}{\partial y} + R \right) \mathrm{d}A $$ where $\mathrm{d}A$ changes depending on the coordinate system used.

item.title: Gradient Vector
item.description: Gradient Vector If $f$ is a [[notes/multivariable-functions|function with two variable]] $x$ and $y$, the gradient of $f$ is the vectorial function $\triangledown f$, and is defined as: $$ \nabla f = \langle \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}, \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} \rangle $$ its main use is in finding the [[notes/directional-derivative|directional derivative]] of a function.

item.title: Graphing in MATLAB
item.description: Graphing in MATLAB Basic Functions plot(x,y) can accept a third argument, which changes the style of the line subplot(a,b,c) lets you have several plots at once, where a is the number of files, b is the number of columns, and c is the location of the current plot.

item.title: Green's Theorem
item.description: Green’s Theorem Supposing that $C$ is a simple closed curve over a range $R$. If $P$ and $Q$, being vectorial functions, and their derivatives are continuous over $R$, then: $$ \oint_C P(x,y)dx+Q(x,y)dy=\iint_R \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial P}{\partial y}dA $$

item.title: Identity Matrix
item.description: Identity Matrix The [[notes/matrix]] $I_n$ is the matrix where all the numbers on the diagonal are $1$, starting from the upper left corner, and everything else is $0$.

item.title: Implication and Associates
item.description: Implication and Associates Let $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ be two defined [[notes/quantifiers|predicates]] in a given universe. Let the quantified proposition be $\forall x [p(x) \to q(x)]$.

item.title: Integration
item.description: Integration Integration can be though as the opposite operation of [[notes/derivation|derivation]], or as finding the sum of all values of a function on some range.

item.title: Inverse Relations
item.description: Inverse Relations Let $R$ be a [[notes/relations|relation]]. The inverse of $R$ is obtained by reversing each pair of ordered numbers inside the relation, and is denoted with $R^{-1}$.

item.title: Irreflexive Relations
item.description: Irreflexive Relations A [[notes/relations|relation]] $R$ is irreflexive if each element in the single set that created the relation is not paired with each itself.

item.title: Lagrange Multiplier
item.description: Lagrange Multiplier Given a [[notes/multivariable-functions|multivariable function]], and a [[notes/constrained-maximum-minimum|constraint]], we use a Lagrange Multiplier, $\lambda$, to find its minimums and maximums.

item.title: Lagrange's Theorem
item.description: Lagrange’s Theorem Lagrange’s theorem states that if a function$f$ has a extrema at $x_0,y_0$, given the restriction $g$, then there exists some value $\lambda$ such that $$ \nabla f(x_0,y_0)=\lambda \cdot \nabla g(x_0,y_0) $$

item.title: Laws of Logical Inference
item.description: Laws of Logical Inference In order to solve [[notes/natural-deduction|natural deduction]] problems, we use the following rules. ![[Files/2022-03-04-085453_675x866_scrot.png]] #logic #formulas

item.title: Line Integral
item.description: Line Integral Line integrals are those where the function is [[notes/integration|integrated]] along a curve on a scalar field or [[vector-field|vector field]].

item.title: Linear Equation Systems
item.description: Linear Equation Systems Linear equation systems A system of linear equations of size $m \times n$, has $m$ equations and $n$ variables, and can be abbreviated as SLE $m \times n$.

item.title: Linear Regression
item.description: Linear Regression A linear regression is a method to predict future values of a function and has the form: $$ y=f(x)=\beta_0+\beta_1x $$ Where $\beta$ are coefficients that define the function.

item.title: Linear Transformations
item.description: Linear Transformations The linear transformation $T: \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m$, where $n$ and $m$ can be $2,3$, is a function that has the following properties:

item.title: Logic
item.description: Logic Logic is a formal science and philosophy that studies thought and its structures. It helps find the truth in [[notes/propositions|statements]], and the arguments between them.

item.title: Logical Connectors
item.description: Logical Connectors Words or symbols that help connect [[notes/propositions]], [[notes/set-theory|sets]], etc. Symbol Connector Name $\neg$ no Negation $\wedge$ and Conjunction $\lor$ or Weak Disjunction $\oplus$ or Exclusive Disjunction $\to$ if Conditional $\leftrightarrow$ if and only if Equivalence #logic

item.title: Magnetism
item.description: Magnetism Magnetic lines emerge from the North pole and enter the South pole. A smaller magnet will align parallel to the magnetic field and its north pole always points in the same direction as the field.

item.title: Matrix
item.description: Matrix Matrices are rectangular arrangements of numbers. $$ A = \begin{bmatrix} a_{11} & a_{21} & \cdots & a_{1n} \ a_{21} & a_{31} & \cdots & a_{2n} \ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \ a_{m1} & a_{m2} & \cdots & a_{mn} \ \end{bmatrix} $$ The matrix $A$ is $m \times n$ big.

item.title: Matrix Addition
item.description: Matrix Addition In order to add two [[notes/matrix|matrices]] they must be the same size, and each element of the matrices must be addable.

item.title: Matrix Multiplication
item.description: Matrix Multiplication When multiplying a matrix by a scalar, each element of the matrix is multiplied by the constant. $$ \begin{align} A= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \ 7 & 5\ \end{bmatrix} && 2A= \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 6 \ 14 & 10 \ \end{bmatrix} \end{align} $$

item.title: Matrix of a System
item.description: Matrix of a System Find the [[notes/matrix]] of the [[notes/linear-equation-systems|system]]: $$ \begin{align} E_1:& 2x_1+3x_2-6x_3=9 \ E_2:& 4x_1+x_2+5x_3=13 \ E_1:& -2x_1+x_2+7x_3=2 \ \end{align} $$ $$ A= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 & -8 \ 4 & 1 & 5 \ -2 & 1 & 7 \ \end{bmatrix} $$ We take the coefficients of every term of our system of equations, and create a matrix with them.

item.title: Matrix Reflection
item.description: Matrix Reflection Reflection on $y$ axis $$ A= \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 \ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} $$ Reflection on $x$ axis $$ A= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \ 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} $$ #math #matrices #linearAlgebra

item.title: Maximum and Minimum with Constrains
item.description: Maximum and Minimum with Constraints When solving problems involving [[notes/maximum-minimum|minimums and maximums]], one can apply a constraint to the function.

item.title: Maximums and Minimums
item.description: Maximums and Minimums These points can be categorized as local or absolute. A local point is the highest/lower point for a specific area, and an absolute point is the highest/lowest point for the entire function.

item.title: Movement on a Curve
item.description: Movement on a Curve The magnitud of the speed function is defined as: $$ |v(t)|=\sqrt{(f'(t))^2+(g'(t))^2+(h'(t))^2} $$ And the length of the arch of the curve, from point $a$ to point $b$ is: $$ L=\int_a^b |v(t)|dt $$ #math #calculus #physics

item.title: Multivariable Functions
item.description: Multivariable Functions As opposed to functions with a single variable, multivariable functions can have several variables as inputs, returning a single output.

item.title: Natural Deduction
item.description: Natural Deduction [[notes/logic|Logic]] allows us to infer, through simple syntactical manipulation, new ideas from old ones. An argument is formed through a series of initial statements call Premises.

item.title: Null Set
item.description: Null Set In [[notes/set-theory|set theory]], the Null Set $\emptyset$ contains nothing ${}$. #logic #setTheory

item.title: Numerical methods for differential equations
item.description: Numerical methods for differential equations [[notes/differential-equations|Differential Equations]] Numerical methods are ways to approximate the original function. Here, we’ll be using Runge-Kutta methods.

item.title: Order of [[notes/compound-propositions|Logical Operations]]
item.description: Order of [[notes/compound-propositions|Logical Operations]] Negation Conjunction Disjunction Conditional Strong Disjunction Biconditional #logic

item.title: Parametric Curves
item.description: Parametric Curves A parametric curve is every curve that depends on some external variable for its creation. Examples can be curves dependent on time, temperature, lengths, etc.

item.title: Parametric Equations
item.description: Parametric Equations Physical phenomena, like the movement of a particle, can be described using a coordinate system $x,y,z$, and with a fourth parameter time.

item.title: Partial Derivatives
item.description: Partial Derivatives [[notes/multivariable-functions|Multivariable functions]] require multivariable derivatives; for each variable in the function, a separate [[notes/derivation|derivative]] is required. How to derive Function $z=f(x,y)$ Partial derivative with to respect to $x$.

item.title: Partial Derivatives in Higher Orders
item.description: Partial Derivatives in Higher Orders One can derive [[notes/partial-derivatives|partial derivatives]] several times, either with respect with one variable or the other.

item.title: Partial Order Relation
item.description: Partial Order Relation A partial order relation is a [[notes/relations|relation]] that is [[notes/irreflexive-relations|irreflexive]], [[notes/partial-order-relation|asymmetric]], and not [[notes/transitive-relations|transitive]]. It is the opposite of an [[notes/equivalence-relation|equivalence relation]].

item.title: Polar Coordinates
item.description: Polar Coordinates On a Cartesian Plane, a point can be can be represented with a length and and angle: $$ P(r,\theta) $$ $r$ is defined as the distance between the point and the origin, and $\theta$ is the angle formed between $r$ and the $x$ axis.

item.title: Polynomial Regression
item.description: Polynomial Regression Like [[notes/linear-regression|linear regressions]], polynomial regressions are ways to predict values of some dataset. These are used when a linear approximation isn’t good enough to fit the values.

item.title: Predicates
item.description: Predicates A predicate is a statement that follows the following three rules: It contains 1 or more variables It’s not a [[notes/propositions|proposition]], but It becomes a proposition when its variables are substituted for concrete values.

item.title: Probability
item.description: Probability Probability is the measure of how sure that some event happens, and is represented as: $$ \mathbb{P}(X) $$ and can give a result between $0$ and $1$.

item.title: Proof by Induction
item.description: Proof by Induction Example Prove using induction: $$ P(n)=1+2+3+\dots + n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2} $$ First, we prove its true for a base case $$ P(1)=\frac{1(2)}{2}=1 $$ Then we assume that $n=k$, $n$ is equal to some number $k$ $$ P(k)=1+2+3+\dots+k=\frac{k(k+1)}{2} $$ Then we check if this is still true for its successor $k+1$ $$ P(k+1)=1+2+3\dots+k+(k+1)=\frac{(k+1)((k+1)+1)}{2} $$ We see that what’s on in the middle part of the equation can be simplified as our case for $k$ $$ \frac{k(k+1)}{2}+(k+1)=\frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2} $$ We continue to simplify terms to check if both sides are equal $$ \begin{align} (k+1)(\frac{k}{2}+1)&=\frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2} \ (k+1)(\frac{k+2}{2})&=\frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2} \ \frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2}&=\frac{(k+1)(k+2)}{2} \ \end{align} $$ Since this outcome is true, our initial statement is true.

item.title: Properties of Matrix Addition and Scalar Multiplication
item.description: Properties of Matrix Addition and Scalar Multiplication The following properties apply both to [[notes/matrix-addition|addition]] and [[notes/matrix-multiplication|multiplication]]: $A + B = B + A$: Commutativity $A + (B+C) = (A+B)+C$: Associativity $A(BC)=(AB)C$: Distributivity $A(B+C)=AB+AC$ $c(AB)=(cA)B=A(cB)$ #math #linearAlgebra #math

item.title: Properties of the Identity Matrix
item.description: Properties of the Identity Matrix If $A$ is a matrix of size $m \times n$, then the following statements are always true:

item.title: Propositions
item.description: Propositions In [[notes/logic]], propositions are statements which must be either true or false. There are 3 states a set of propositions can have:

item.title: Quadratic surfaces
item.description: Quadratic surfaces The equation of a quadratic surface is a second grade equation of the form $$Ax^2+By^2+Cz^2+Dxy+Exz+Fyz+Gx+Hy+Hz+J=0$$ There are 6 basic quadratic surfaces:

item.title: Quantifiers
item.description: Quantifiers $\forall$ is the universal quantifier $\exists$ is the existential quantifier Statements with expressions like: some, there exists, there are some, for all, every, etc, are existential quantifiers and universal quantifiers respectively.

item.title: R Programming Language
item.description: R Programming Language Programming language used for the analysis and visualization of data. Data Types Type Example Integer 1 Numeric 1.

item.title: Random Variable
item.description: Random Variable In [[notes/probability]], a random variable are the outcomes of different events.

item.title: Reflexive Relations
item.description: Reflexive Relations A [[notes/relations|relation]] $R$ is reflexive if each element in the single set that created the relation is paired with each itself.

item.title: Relations
item.description: Relations A relations is a [[notes/set-theory|set]] of ordered pairs created by taking elements from either a single set $A$, or two sets $A$, $B$.

item.title: Rotation Matrix
item.description: Rotation Matrix $$ A_\theta = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(\theta) & -\sin(\theta) \ \sin(\theta) & \cos(\theta) \ \end{bmatrix} $$ Multiplying this [[notes/matrix]] with a vector in $\mathbb{R}^2$ will rotate it.

item.title: Scalar Field
item.description: Scalar Field

item.title: Set Complement
item.description: Set Complement The complement of set $A$ is every element in the [[notes/universal-set|universal set]] that’s not in $A$. It’s denoted with $A^c$, $\bar{A}$, or $A'$.

item.title: Set Difference
item.description: Set Difference Difference: The difference of sets $A$ and $B$ in the [[notes/universal-set|universal set]] $U$ is $$A - B = { x \in A | x \notin B }$$ #logic #setTheory

item.title: Set Intersection
item.description: Set Intersection Intersection: If $A$ and $B$ are sets in the [[notes/universal-set|universal set]] $U$, the intersection of these sets is defined as $$A \cap B = { x \in U | x \in A \land x \in B }$$ #logic #setTheory

item.title: Set theory
item.description: Set theory Sets are collections of things that are similar. Uppercase letters $A, B, C$ are used to denote the names of sets.

item.title: Set Union
item.description: Set Union Union: The union of sets $A$ and $B$ in the [[notes/universal-set|universal set]] $U$ is defined as $$A \cup B = { x \in U | x \in A \lor x \in B }$$ #logic #setTheory

item.title: SigFig Arithmetic
item.description: SigFig Arithmetic Rule: adding or subtracting [[notes/significant-figures|numbers with decimals]], the number of decimals of the answer is equal to the number with the least amount of decimal places.

item.title: Significant Figures
item.description: Significant Figures If there’s no decimal point, start counting from the right and skip zeroes. If there’s a decimal point, count from the left and skip zeros.

item.title: Singleton
item.description: Singleton In [[notes/set-theory|set theory]], a singleton is a set containing a single element. #logic #setTheory

item.title: SLE Solution
item.description: SLE Solution The solution of a [[notes/linear-equation-systems|SLE]] is a vector that gives identities to all variables. Example: The vector $\vec{x} = \mycolv{2\1}$ solves the equations:

item.title: Spheres
item.description: Spheres Formal Definition A sphere is the group of all points in [[notes/coordinate-systems-in-3-dimensions|3 dimensional space]] that are equidistant from some point $C(h,j,l)$.

item.title: Stokes Theorem
item.description: Stoke’s Theorem Stoke’s theorem can be considered an extension of [[notes/greens-theorem|green’s theorem]], and can be generalized to calculate the work done over a volume.

item.title: Subsets
item.description: Subsets When dealing with [[notes/set-theory|sets]], we can say that certain sets are subsets of other sets. $A$ is a subset of $B$ if and only if every element in $A$ is also an element of $B$.

item.title: Surface Integrals
item.description: Surface Integrals Surface integrals are ways to integrate surfaces. This is done by converting the function defining the surface, normally defined as $r$, into coordinates, $u$ and $v$.

item.title: Syllogism
item.description: Syllogism Argument that uses [[notes/natural-deduction|deductive reasoning]] to reach a conclusion. #logic

item.title: Symmetric Relations
item.description: Symmetric Relations A [[notes/relations|relation]] $R$ is symmetric if each pair of different elements has its inverse in the relation. $$ xRy \to yRx $$

item.title: Tangent Plane
item.description: Tangent Plane The infinitely small point on $z=f(x,y)$ is flat, and if we were to extend it infinitely across [[notes/coordinate-systems-in-3-dimensions|3 dimensions]], we’ll get a tangent plane to the original surface.

item.title: Taylor Series
item.description: Taylor series Taylor series are a way of predicting the value of a function at some point in terms of the value of the function plus its derivatives at a different point.

item.title: Tensors
item.description: Tensors Tensors are completely abstract ways of thinking about vectors and scalars: 0th order tensor: Scalar 1st order tensor: Vector 2nd order tensor: Matrix

item.title: Total Differential
item.description: Total Differential Let $z=f(x,y)$ be a [[notes/multivariable-functions|multivariable function]] and $dx$ and $dy$ infinitely small changes in $x$ and $y$ respectively. How do we determine the total change in $z$?

item.title: Transitive Relations
item.description: Transitive Relations A [[notes/relations|relation]] $R$ is transitive if we can find a [[notes/laws-of-logical-inference|hypothetical syllogism]] within its elements. $$ (xRy)\land(yRz) \to xRz $$

item.title: Truth Tables
item.description: Truth Tables Truth tables evaluate the results of [[notes/logical-connectors|compound propositions]] by evaluating each [[notes/propositions|simple proposition]] and [[notes/evaluating-arguments|finding their value]]. The number of possibilities is equal to $2^n$, where $n$ is the number of simple propositions.

item.title: Universal Set
item.description: Universal Set In [[notes/set-theory|set theory]], the Universal Set $U$ contains all the considered elements. #logic #setTheory

item.title: Universe and Solution Set
item.description: Universe and Solution Set Let $P$ be a [[notes/predicates|predicate]]. The universe $U$ is the [[notes/set-theory|set]] that entails all the possible values for the variables in $P$.

item.title: Variance
item.description: Variance Variance is an indicator that shows us how far away we are from a [[notes/expected-value|expected value]], and is defined as: $$ \hat{\sigma}^2 \frac{\Sigma_{i=1}^{N}(x_{i}-\overline{x})^2}{N-1} $$

item.title: Vector
item.description: Vector A vector is a [[notes/matrix]] in 2 dimensions, e.i, $1\times m$ or $n \times1$.

item.title: Vector Field
item.description: Vector Field A vector field is every field where each point is subjected to some function. They’re are commonly represented as fields with arrows, representing the [[vector|vectors]].

item.title: Vector Spaces
item.description: Vector Spaces A vector space is any space with elements, called vectors. $$ \textbf{A}=\hat{x}A_x+\hat{y}A_y+\hat{z}A_z $$ Where each component of the base is a unit.

item.title: Volume and Double Integrals
item.description: Volume and Double Integrals We can use [[notes/double-integration|double integrals]] to find the volumes of solids. If $f(x,y)\geq 0$, then the volume $V$ of the solid that is between the plane and below the surface $f$ is: $$ V=\iint_Rf(x,y)dA $$ where $R$ is the region being integrated, and the differential of area $dA$, is equal to the product of the differential on $x$ and on $y$.

item.title: Volume Flow Rate
item.description: Volume Flow Rate Volume flow rate is the rate at which volume flows, and is measured in Volume per Time. $$ Q=Av $$

item.title: Zero Matrix
item.description: Zero Matrix The [[notes/matrix]] $0_{mn}$ is the matrix of size $m \times n$ filled only with zeros. If using multiple digit numbers, a comma must be used between them.
